justification: The Methods state that participants "filled out two measures of apathy (Apathy Evaluation Scale, AES …)."
Participants also completed the "Apathy Motivation Index" which is listed as one of the "two measures of apathy."
The article notes that impulsivity was assessed with "two validated self-report questionnaire measures of impulsivity (Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, BIS-11 …)."
The same sentence lists the "Urgency, Premeditation (lack of), Perseverance (lack of), Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale, UPPS-P" as the second instrument for impulsivity.
In the Introduction the authors remark that apathy can be observed "in dedicated tasks (e.g., apathy: Effort-Based Decision-Making task …)."
The same list of dedicated tasks for apathy includes the "Option Generation task" as an instrument where apathetic behaviour is measured.
For impulsivity, the paper cites the "Balloon Analogue Risk-Taking task" as a task where the trait "can be observed in isolation."
The Introduction also lists the "Cued Go No-Go task" as a dedicated paradigm for observing impulsive behaviour.
The study employed "a new version of the Traffic Light Task (TLT)—a task known to encourage impulsive behaviour" and later calls it "an established measure of rapid decision-making for reward."
During the experiment "participants were asked to rate their level of subjective fatigue" on "a vertical visual analogue scale (VAS)"—the instrument used to quantify the fatigue construct.
